Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Bats in the agricultural matrix: impacts on diversity, distribution and ecosystem services
Award.AbstractNarration:
Agricultural land use change transforms landscapes from complex, natural habitat to simple, agricultural systems. These landscape changes negatively affect bats, and may result in the loss of agricultural pest suppression by insectivorous bats. In California's Central Coast, the fertile soil and temperate climate are ideal for growing high-value crops, such as fruits and vegetables, but the region is also important habitat for wildlife, including 16 species of bats. Bats are voracious insect predators and protecting bats in agricultural areas can help to control pests and reduce the need for pesticides. This research investigates which farm management practices are bat-friendly and could promote bat-mediated pest suppression, and which practices may deter bats from visiting certain farms.

The researchers will use meta-analysis, observational and experimental field methods, and new lab technologies to examine the multi-scalar effects of agricultural intensification on insectivorous bats and bat-insect interactions. Ultrasonic recorders will be used to reveal patterns of bat diversity, and a novel technique (removal of tethered moths) will be tested and described to document bat removal of pests in the field. Bats will be tracked using radio telemetry to map home ranges and understand foraging ecology. Fecal DNA analysis will be used to characterize bat diets and identify trophic linkages between bats and agriculturally important insect pests. Understanding spillover effects between natural and managed systems is relevant to conservation biologists, agroecologists, and land managers. This research will allow for relative valuation of entire bat communities, and the knowledge generated will promote conservation of these charismatic organisms. Research findings will be shared with scientists and the public through scientific journals, conferences, and outreach to local farming communities about bat conservation. In addition, the research will incorporate individual mentoring of women and minority students, and high-school curriculum development for students in a migrant, Latino community. Undergraduate assistants from UC Santa Cruz's diverse student body will be encouraged to develop synergies between this research and potential thesis projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many species that live in highly managed agricultural systems directly influence our food supply. Insect-eating bats are important predators that help to keep agricultural pest populations in check and are estimated to be worth $3.7 billion annually to US agriculture. Although intensive farming practices can have detrimental effects on bat populations and bat-mediated pest suppression, our research focuses on the benefits of management practices designed in harmony with the environment as a powerful approach to offset the potential negative effects of intensive agricultural practices. 

We explored the effects of local and landscape scale management of woody vegetation on bats and their insect prey in the farmlands of California’s Central Coast. Many bats depend upon forested habitat for roosting and commuting between roost sites and foraging areas, but woodlands are often limited to small strips along waterways in intensive agricultural landscapes. At the local scale, we found that bat activity was higher along woodland edges and decreased with distance from an edge into a crop field, suggesting that bats provide greater pest suppression near woodlands than over vast expanses of open crop fields. Previous research supports the benefits of woodlands for agriculturally-important beneficial insects and birds, and our findings extend these benefits to include bats. 

At the landscape scale, we found that remnant woodlands in intensive agricultural habitats have high value for bat conservation, as bat activity tends to be concentrated in these areas.  We found that some sensitive bat species were rarely recorded over vast expanses of crop fields and in landscapes with very little remnant woodland. Protecting and restoring woodlands in intensive agricultural landscapes, where forested habitat is scarce, can help to increase the efficacy of agricultural conservation efforts. 

Our research also aims to understand how the amount of surrounding woodland habitat affects bat diets, and to identify which insect pests bats consume. Using advanced molecular techniques, we identified insect DNA from guano samples to reconstruct bat diets. Our results confirm that bats consume common agricultural pests in California, and we are working to assess how landscape context affects which insect species bats consume. Identifying, protecting, and promoting the characteristics of farms and the surrounding landscape that promote insect­eating bats has the potential to reduce application rates of toxic pesticides, as well as their associated negative impacts on human health and the environment. 

Research findings will continue to be shared with scientists and the public through scientific journals, conferences, and outreach to local farming communities about bat conservation. This also research incorporated individual mentoring of women and minority students, and high-school curriculum development for students in a migrant, Latino community. Twelve undergraduate students participated in internships related to this research and gained hands-on field, laboratory, and analytical skills. As a postdoctoral fellow, I will continue to study conservation and agriculture in the same study system, where I will have a longer-term ability to share research findings and strengthen relationships between scientists, farmers, and land managers.
